column3: This would have an undesirable effect on testnet.\n
@btcdrak This PR only has an effect on mainnet.\n
Assuming that miners runnning master already have their own patch set, how would this prevent them from creating a toggle-fDisableMiningOnNonreleaseBranches-patch?\n

I'm not sure how efficient this change is.
`fDisableMiningOnNonreleaseBranches` could be an additional obstacle for mining pools running patches/extended versions of core.
Sure, they could just pass in a `CLIENT_VERSION_IS_RELEASE` but would this be the appropriate (patch Bitcoin Core, flag it as `CLIENT_VERSION_IS_RELEASE`)?
I think @sipa's idea of not adding the soft fork to the mainnet parameters is better so I'm closing this.\n

> Assuming that miners runnning master already have their own patch set, how would this prevent them from creating a toggle-fDisableMiningOnNonreleaseBranches-patch?\n\nNothing does. But apparently people randomly check out Bitcoin Core without being aware of the risks of mining on master. Requiring an explicit source code change (especially if the source is commented as to _why_) puts up a stupid

Sure, but the same is a barrier to _test_ mainnet-mining on master: E.g. "Let me quickly check if this bug is in master, too" or "Let's see if I need to change my workflow for the next bitcoin release by checking if current master breaks anything"...\n\nIt should be common sense that running bitcoin (especially master) could lead to monetary losses and adding such checks is just a unnecessary bloa
